elements.content: Here we report a fluorescent magnesium coordination polymer (Mg-CP), namely, [CH3-dpb]2[Mg3(1,4-NDC)4(μ-H2O)2(CH3OH)­(H2O)]·1.5H2O (1, 1,4-H2NDC = 1,4-naphthalene dicarboxylic acid, dpb = 1,4-bis­(pyrid-4-yl)­benzene). Compound 1 possesses a three-dimensional (3D) host–guest structure constructed by the 1,4-NDC linkers bridging the linear trinuclear secondary building units of [Mg3(COO)8(μ-H2O)2]. The dpb molecules were in situ reacted with CH3OH resulting in photochromic cations of [CH3-dpb]+ that acted as guests located in the channels parallel to the b-axis. Photoluminescence (PL) studies indicated that 1 showed a strong green emission demonstrating sensitive fluorescence sensing of Fe3+/Cr3+ metal ions and nitro-explosive compounds. Compound 1 represents the first PL Mg-CP as a fluorescent probe for detecting metal ions. Moreover, because of the in situ encapsulation of photochromic [CH3-dpb]+ guests, 1 exhibited reversible photochromic behavior.
elements.clean_text: Here we report a fluorescent magnesium coordination polymer (Mg-CP), namely, [CH3-dpb]2[Mg3(1,4-NDC)4(μ-H2O)2(CH3OH)(H2O)]⋅1.5H2O (1, 1,4-H2NDC = 1,4-naphthalene dicarboxylic acid, dpb = 1,4-bis(pyrid-4-yl)benzene). Compound 1 possesses a three-dimensional (3D) host-guest structure constructed by the 1,4-NDC linkers bridging the linear trinuclear secondary building units of [Mg3(COO)8(μ-H2O)2]. The dpb molecules were in situ reacted with CH3OH resulting in photochromic cations of [CH3-dpb]+ that acted as guests located in the channels parallel to the b-axis. Photoluminescence (PL) studies indicated that 1 showed a strong green emission demonstrating sensitive fluorescence sensing of Fe3+/Cr3+ metal ions and nitro-explosive compounds. Compound 1 represents the first PL Mg-CP as a fluorescent probe for detecting metal ions. Moreover, because of the in situ encapsulation of photochromic [CH3-dpb]+ guests, 1 exhibited reversible photochromic behavior.

elements.content: Presented is the synthesis and characterizations of a fluorescent 3D Mg-CP, namely, [CH3-dpb]2[Mg3(1,4-NDC)4(μ-H2O)2(CH3OH)­(H2O)]·1.5H2O (1), demonstrating photochromic behavior and sensitive fluorescence sensing for Fe3+/Cr3+ ions and nitro-explosive compounds.
elements.clean_text: Presented is the synthesis and characterizations of a fluorescent 3D Mg-CP, namely, [CH3-dpb]2[Mg3(1,4-NDC)4(μ-H2O)2(CH3OH)(H2O)]⋅1.5H2O (1), demonstrating photochromic behavior and sensitive fluorescence sensing for Fe3+/Cr3+ ions and nitro-explosive compounds.

elements.content: Recently, photoluminescent (PL) materials have been widely explored as chemosensors for detecting hazardous substances concerning environmental and humanitarian implications. As we know, the trace metal ions usually are essential in biological metabolism, while the excess metal ions would bring great harm to the human body and biological environment. For instance, the excess Fe3+ existing in a living cell can cause damage to nucleic acids and proteins, whereas the excess Cr3+ can lead to deformity, and Cr-containing wastes have also became an important environmental issue. On the other hand, nitroaromatic compounds have become serious pollution sources due to their high toxicity and the following security issue. Hence, it remains a significant but a challenging research topic to explore new type of sensors for detecting these metal ions and nitroaromatic compounds rapidly and selectively.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently, photoluminescent (PL) materials have been widely explored as chemosensors for detecting hazardous substances concerning environmental and humanitarian implications. As we know, the trace metal ions usually are essential in biological metabolism, while the excess metal ions would bring great harm to the human body and biological environment. For instance, the excess Fe3+ existing in a living cell can cause damage to nucleic acids and proteins, whereas the excess Cr3+ can lead to deformity, and Cr-containing wastes have also became an important environmental issue. On the other hand, nitroaromatic compounds have become serious pollution sources due to their high toxicity and the following security issue. Hence, it remains a significant but a challenging research topic to explore new type of sensors for detecting these metal ions and nitroaromatic compounds rapidly and selectively.

elements.content: Photoluminescent coordination polymers (PL-CPs) have undergone tremendous development over the past few decades, exhibiting numerously potential applications such as lighting emission, bioimaging, and fluorescence probing. The fluorescent sensing of PL-CPs for organic molecules and metal ions has been widely studied. As a matter of fact, most of the reported PL-CPs thus far are based on the lanthanide or transition-metal ions. By contrast, the PL-CPs containing the main-group alkaline-earth metal ions have been rarely explored. Recently, we are focusing our attention in constructing Mg2+-based PL-CPs and explore their potential PL applications. Our studies demonstrated that the Mg2+ possessing a unique electron configuration is a good candidate for constructing PL-CPs owing to its linker-centered emission, low-cost, biocompatibility, etc.
elements.clean_text: Photoluminescent coordination polymers (PL-CPs) have undergone tremendous development over the past few decades, exhibiting numerously potential applications such as lighting emission, bioimaging, and fluorescence probing. The fluorescent sensing of PL-CPs for organic molecules and metal ions has been widely studied. As a matter of fact, most of the reported PL-CPs thus far are based on the lanthanide or transition-metal ions. By contrast, the PL-CPs containing the main-group alkaline-earth metal ions have been rarely explored. Recently, we are focusing our attention in constructing Mg2+-based PL-CPs and explore their potential PL applications. Our studies demonstrated that the Mg2+ possessing a unique electron configuration is a good candidate for constructing PL-CPs owing to its linker-centered emission, low-cost, biocompatibility, etc.

elements.content: In this paper, a PL-Mg-CP, namely, [CH3-dpb]2­[Mg3(1,4-NDC)4­(μ-H2O)2­(CH3OH)­(H2O)]·1.5H2O (1, 1,4-H2NDC = 1,4-naphthalene dicarboxylic acid, dpb = 1,4-bis­(pyrid-4-yl)­benzene), was synthesized and characterized. In compound 1, the 1,4-NDC linkers bridge the linear trinuclear secondary building units (SBUs) of [Mg3(COO)8(μ-H2O)2] to form a new three-dimensional (3D) host framework, and the dpb molecules were in situ reacted with methanol to form the photochromic cations of [CH3-dpb]+, which acted as guests located in the one-dimensional (1D) channels parallel to the crystallographic b-axis. Remarkably, fluorescence measurements indicated that the title compound not only could be used as a rapid and efficient fluorescent sensor for Fe3+ and Cr3+ ions but also demonstrated a sensitive luminescent probing for trace nitro-explosives compounds. To our knowledge, compound 1 reported here is the first PL-Mg-CP as a fluorescent probe for metal ions. Moreover, because of the in situ encapsulation of photochromic guest, 1 exhibited an unusual photochromic behavior showing reversible color changes.
elements.clean_text: In this paper, a PL-Mg-CP, namely, [CH3-dpb]2[Mg3(1,4-NDC)4(μ-H2O)2(CH3OH)(H2O)]⋅1.5H2O (1, 1,4-H2NDC = 1,4-naphthalene dicarboxylic acid, dpb = 1,4-bis(pyrid-4-yl)benzene), was synthesized and characterized. In compound 1, the 1,4-NDC linkers bridge the linear trinuclear secondary building units (SBUs) of [Mg3(COO)8(μ-H2O)2] to form a new three-dimensional (3D) host framework, and the dpb molecules were in situ reacted with methanol to form the photochromic cations of [CH3-dpb]+, which acted as guests located in the one-dimensional (1D) channels parallel to the crystallographic b-axis. Remarkably, fluorescence measurements indicated that the title compound not only could be used as a rapid and efficient fluorescent sensor for Fe3+ and Cr3+ ions but also demonstrated a sensitive luminescent probing for trace nitro-explosives compounds. To our knowledge, compound 1 reported here is the first PL-Mg-CP as a fluorescent probe for metal ions. Moreover, because of the in situ encapsulation of photochromic guest, 1 exhibited an unusual photochromic behavior showing reversible color changes.

elements.content: All the chemicals were used without further purification. Elemental analyses (EA) of C, H, and N were performed using a German Elementary Vario EL III instrument. The UV–vis diffuse reflectance (DR) analyses were recorded at room temperature using a Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrophotometer. A BaSO4 plate was used as a standard (100% reflectance). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed with a NETZSCH STA449C at a heating rate of 5 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained from a Miniflex II diffractometer at 30 kV and 15 mA using Cu Kα (1.541 78 Å) in the angular range of 2θ = 3–65° at room temperature. Electron spin resonance (ESR) signals and fluorescence spectra were recorded with a Bruker A300 spectrometer and a PerkinElmer LS55 fluorescence spectrometer, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Experiment Section

Materials and Methods

All the chemicals were used without further purification. Elemental analyses (EA) of C, H, and N were performed using a German Elementary Vario EL III instrument. The UV-vis diffuse reflectance (DR) analyses were recorded at room temperature using a Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrophotometer. A BaSO4 plate was used as a standard (100% reflectance). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed with a NETZSCH STA449C at a heating rate of 5 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained from a Miniflex II diffractometer at 30 kV and 15 mA using Cu Kα (1.54178 Å) in the angular range of 2θ = 3-65° at room temperature. Electron spin resonance (ESR) signals and fluorescence spectra were recorded with a Bruker A300 spectrometer and a PerkinElmer LS55 fluorescence spectrometer, respectively.

elements.content: The reactants of Mg­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.256 g, 1 mmol), 1,4-H2NDC (0.216 g, 1 mmol), dpb (0.232 g, 1 mmol), and NaOH (0.080 g, 2 mmol) were mixed with 2 mL of CH3OH and 2 mL of H2O, and then the mixture was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and kept at 160 °C for 6 d. After the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, the blocklike yellow crystals were obtained after filtered, washed with ethanol several times, dried naturally, and selected manually under an optical microscope (0.120 g, yield: 23% based on magnesium). Anal. Calcd for 1: C, 64.84%; H, 4.39%; N, 3.64%. Found: C, 63.46%; H, 4.35%; N, 3.59%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compound 1 

The reactants of Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.256 g, 1 mmol), 1,4-H2NDC (0.216 g, 1 mmol), dpb (0.232 g, 1 mmol), and NaOH (0.080 g, 2 mmol) were mixed with 2 mL of CH3OH and 2 mL of H2O, and then the mixture was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and kept at 160 °C for 6 d. After the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, the blocklike yellow crystals were obtained after filtered, washed with ethanol several times, dried naturally, and selected manually under an optical microscope (0.120 g, yield: 23% based on magnesium). Anal. Calcd for 1: C, 64.84%; H, 4.39%; N, 3.64%. Found: C, 63.46%; H, 4.35%; N, 3.59%.

elements.content: The 2 mg of fine powder of 1 was added to 2 mL of solvents of methanol, ethanol, CH2Cl2, CHCl3, acetone, N,N-diethylformamide (DEF), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), n-propane, ethylene glycol, dimethylformamide (DMF), N-methylformamide (NMF), tetrahydrofuran (THF), ethyl ether, and acetonitrile, respectively. After ultrasonic treatment for a few minutes, the powder of 1 was well-dispersed into these solvents to form a stable turbid liquid. Detailed detections for all titrants were performed by gradually adding 1.0 × 10–2 M ethanol solution of Fe3+ and Cr3+, 5.0 × 10–3 M ethanol solution of trinitrophenol (TNP), 2,4-dinitraniline, p-nitraniline, and o-nitrophenol, respectively, into the suspension of 1 that was placed in a 1 cm width quartz cell with an incremental fashion. A pipet was utilized to add the quenchers into the emulsion for convenience of calculations of the sensing concentrations. Fluorescence detection measurements were performed at 298 K, and the suspensions of 1 were excited at λex = 430 nm with emission wavelengths ranging from 450 to 650 nm. The fluorescence efficiency percentage was calculated by [(I 0 – I)/I 0] × 100, where I 0 is the initial fluorescence intensity.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Detection Measurements

The 2 mg of fine powder of 1 was added to 2 mL of solvents of methanol, ethanol, CH2Cl2, CHCl3, acetone, N,N-diethylformamide (DEF), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), n-propane, ethylene glycol, dimethylformamide (DMF), N-methylformamide (NMF), tetrahydrofuran (THF), ethyl ether, and acetonitrile, respectively. After ultrasonic treatment for a few minutes, the powder of 1 was well-dispersed into these solvents to form a stable turbid liquid. Detailed detections for all titrants were performed by gradually adding 1.0 × 10-2 M ethanol solution of Fe3+ and Cr3+, 5.0 × 10-3 M ethanol solution of trinitrophenol (TNP), 2,4-dinitraniline, p-nitraniline, and o-nitrophenol, respectively, into the suspension of 1 that was placed in a 1 cm width quartz cell with an incremental fashion. A pipet was utilized to add the quenchers into the emulsion for convenience of calculations of the sensing concentrations. Fluorescence detection measurements were performed at 298 K, and the suspensions of 1 were excited at λex = 430 nm with emission wavelengths ranging from 450 to 650 nm. The fluorescence efficiency percentage was calculated by [(I 0 - I)/I 0] × 100, where I 0 is the initial fluorescence intensity.

elements.content: Intensity data collections of 1 were performed on a SuperNova Oxford diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.541 84 Å) at 100 K. The structure of 1 was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELX-2016 program package. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters, and the hydrogen atoms attached to the C atoms were located at geometrically calculated positions, while those attached to the O atoms were added according to the difference-Fourier syntheses. The terminal solvent molecules were found to be one CH3OH and one H2O molecule per formula that disorderly occupied the same position with SOF ratio of 0.5:0.5. As a result, the free solvent molecules in the asymmetric unit are 0.75 H2O distributed over two positions with SOFs of 0.25 and 0.5, respectively. The empirical formula was further confirmed by TGA and EA. Important crystallographic data and structure-refinement parameters for compound 1 are listed in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Intensity data collections of 1 were performed on a SuperNova Oxford diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å) at 100 K. The structure of 1 was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELX-2016 program package. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters, and the hydrogen atoms attached to the C atoms were located at geometrically calculated positions, while those attached to the O atoms were added according to the difference-Fourier syntheses. The terminal solvent molecules were found to be one CH3OH and one H2O molecule per formula that disorderly occupied the same position with SOF ratio of 0.5:0.5. As a result, the free solvent molecules in the asymmetric unit are 0.75 H2O distributed over two positions with SOFs of 0.25 and 0.5, respectively. The empirical formula was further confirmed by TGA and EA. Important crystallographic data and structure-refinement parameters for compound 1 are listed in .

elements.content:
Crystallographic Data for Compound <bold>1</bold> empirical formula C83H67Mg3N4O21.50 formula weight 1537.33 crystal system monoclinic space group P21/n a/Ǻ 13.8496(2) b/Ǻ 17.4765(3) c/Ǻ 14.8809(2) β/deg 91.5210(10) V/Å3 3600.54(9) Z 2 λ/Ǻ 1.541 84 T/K 100(2) ρcalcd/g cm–3 1.418 μ/mm–1 1.087 F(000) 1602 independent refls 7128 No. of parameters 546 R 1 (I > 2σ(I)) 0.0403 wR(F 2) (I > 2σ (I)) 0.0971

R 1 = ∑||F 0|−|F c||/∑|F 0|.

wR 2 = [ ∑w(F 0 2–F c 2)2/∑w(F 0 2)2]1/2.

Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that compound 1 has a 3D structure with the P21 /n space group. There are 1.5 crystallographically unique Mg2+ ions, two 1,4-NDC ligands, 0.5 terminal CH3OH/H2O, one μ-H2O, one [CH3-dpb]+ cation, and 0.75 H2O (Figure S1, Supporting Information) in the asymmetric unit of 1. As shown in a, the Mg(1) adopts an octahedral coordination geometry surrounded by four O atoms coming from four different 1,4-NDC ligands in the equatorial plane and two O atoms of μ-H2O and disordered terminal methanol/H2O molecules in the apical sites. While the Mg(2) atom residing in an inversion center forms a nearly perfect octahedron with six O atoms, four of which in the equatorial plane also come from four different carboxylate groups and two of which are from two μ-H2O molecules. Subsequently, two Mg(1) and one Mg(2) are interlinked by four bridging COO– groups and two μ-H2O molecules to form a centrosymmetric linear trinuclear unit of [Mg3(COO)8(μ-H2O)2] acting as the SBU for compound 1. Such linear SBU has been commonly reported. The Mg–O bond distance fall in the range between 1.9934(12) and 2.138(12) Å. Every SBU is interconnected by the 1,4-NDC linkers to eight neighboring SBUs resulting in a 3D host framework with 1D tunnels along the b-axis, c. Note that the [CH3-dpb]+ cations were in situ generated by the reaction of dpb and methanol molecules under solvothermal conditions, . The terminal solvent molecules, the [CH3-dpb]+ cations, together with the uncoordinated lattice water molecules acting as guests, all are located in the channels along the b-axis, d. Taking the trinuclear SBU as an 8-connected node, compound 1 exhibits a known 4·6 topology, e.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure Descriptions

Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that compound 1 has a 3D structure with the P21 /n space group. There are 1.5 crystallographically unique Mg2+ ions, two 1,4-NDC ligands, 0.5 terminal CH3OH/H2O, one μ-H2O, one [CH3-dpb]+ cation, and 0.75 H2O (Figure S1, Supporting Information) in the asymmetric unit of 1. As shown in a, the Mg(1) adopts an octahedral coordination geometry surrounded by four O atoms coming from four different 1,4-NDC ligands in the equatorial plane and two O atoms of μ-H2O and disordered terminal methanol/H2O molecules in the apical sites. While the Mg(2) atom residing in an inversion center forms a nearly perfect octahedron with six O atoms, four of which in the equatorial plane also come from four different carboxylate groups and two of which are from two μ-H2O molecules. Subsequently, two Mg(1) and one Mg(2) are interlinked by four bridging COO- groups and two μ-H2O molecules to form a centrosymmetric linear trinuclear unit of [Mg3(COO)8(μ-H2O)2] acting as the SBU for compound 1. Such linear SBU has been commonly reported. The Mg-O bond distance fall in the range between 1.9934(12) and 2.138(12) Å. Every SBU is interconnected by the 1,4-NDC linkers to eight neighboring SBUs resulting in a 3D host framework with 1D tunnels along the b-axis, c. Note that the [CH3-dpb]+ cations were in situ generated by the reaction of dpb and methanol molecules under solvothermal conditions, . The terminal solvent molecules, the [CH3-dpb]+ cations, together with the uncoordinated lattice water molecules acting as guests, all are located in the channels along the b-axis, d. Taking the trinuclear SBU as an 8-connected node, compound 1 exhibits a known 4⋅6 topology, e.

elements.content: (a) Linear trinuclear unit as SBU in 1 (symmetry code: i = 1 – x, −y, −z). (b) Coordination mode of the unique 1,4-NDC linkers in 1. (c) 3D skeleton of 1 viewed along the b-axis; guest cations and solvent molecules in the channels are not shown for clarity. (d) 3D framework of 1 displayed along the b-axis with the cationic guests of [CH3-dpb]+ (shown in light blue) in the channels. (e) Topology of compound 1.

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Diagram for the in Situ Formation of CH3-dpb Cation

elements.content: As depicted in , the solid-state compound 1 exhibits intense green light emission of 490 nm (λex = 430 nm) at 298 K with a nanosecond lifetime (Figure S2, Supporting Information) and a 13.62% quantum yield. Compound 1 can be further coated onto a 360 nm UV light to emit bright green light, inset of . As we know, the viologen-typed molecules easily undergo photoinduced reduction resulting in weak or no fluorescence when excited by UV light. Thus, the fluorescence of the title compound should mainly originate from the Mg-CP host framework. Furthermore, the fluorescence of 1 can be tentatively ascribed to the intraligand electronic transition as that the free ligand of 1,4-H2NDC exhibits an similar emission at λmax = 500 nm, Figure S3 of Supporting Information. When 1,4-NDC is coordinated to Mg2+ ion, the rigidity and the π-conjugacy of the ligand were enhanced, resulting in the more bright fluorescence of 1 compared with that of the free 1,4-H2NDC. Further investigation indicated that compound 1 could be well-dispersed in many solvents such as CH2Cl2, DMF, and DMA to form stable turbid liquids. The resultant suspensions showed emission bands with slight blue shift compared with that of the solid-state 1, Figure S6 of Supporting Information. Notably, in CH2Cl2 compound 1 demonstrated the strongest fluorescence emission. Thus, CH2Cl2 was chosen as the dispersed solvent to find the potential fluorescence detection of 1 for the metal ions and nitro-explosive compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Measurements

As depicted in , the solid-state compound 1 exhibits intense green light emission of 490 nm (λex = 430 nm) at 298 K with a nanosecond lifetime (Figure S2, Supporting Information) and a 13.62% quantum yield. Compound 1 can be further coated onto a 360 nm UV light to emit bright green light, inset of . As we know, the viologen-typed molecules easily undergo photoinduced reduction resulting in weak or no fluorescence when excited by UV light. Thus, the fluorescence of the title compound should mainly originate from the Mg-CP host framework. Furthermore, the fluorescence of 1 can be tentatively ascribed to the intraligand electronic transition as that the free ligand of 1,4-H2NDC exhibits an similar emission at λmax = 500 nm, Figure S3 of Supporting Information. When 1,4-NDC is coordinated to Mg2+ ion, the rigidity and the π-conjugacy of the ligand were enhanced, resulting in the more bright fluorescence of 1 compared with that of the free 1,4-H2NDC. Further investigation indicated that compound 1 could be well-dispersed in many solvents such as CH2Cl2, DMF, and DMA to form stable turbid liquids. The resultant suspensions showed emission bands with slight blue shift compared with that of the solid-state 1, Figure S6 of Supporting Information. Notably, in CH2Cl2 compound 1 demonstrated the strongest fluorescence emission. Thus, CH2Cl2 was chosen as the dispersed solvent to find the potential fluorescence detection of 1 for the metal ions and nitro-explosive compounds.

elements.content: Solid-state fluorescence spectra of 1. (inset) A photograph of the LED coated with a thin layer of 1 (left) and UV-LED lamp (right) both in state of turn-on.
elements.clean_text: 2  Solid-state fluorescence spectra of 1. (inset) A photograph of the LED coated with a thin layer of 1 (left) and UV-LED lamp (right) both in state of turn-on.

elements.content: To investigate if compound 1 can be utilized as a fluorescence probe for sensing metal ions, the fluorescence of 1 dispersed in various 1 × 10–2 M ethanol solutions of metal ions M­(NO3) n (M = Li+, Ca2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Co2+, Mn2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Ag+, Cr3+, Fe3+) were recorded under excitation at 430 nm. As can been seen in and Figure S7 of Supporting Information, compared with that of the blank sample, the fluorescence intensities of the suspensions were significantly quenched when Fe3+ and Cr3+ ions were added (Figure S8, Supporting Information), while other metal ions only slightly affect the emission intensities. Thus, to explore the sensing sensitivity, we dispersed 2 mg of powder of compound 1 in 2 mL of CH2Cl2 solvent to monitor its emissive response toward the two trivalent metal ions with 1 × 10–2 M concentration. As can be seen in a, the fluorescence intensities of 1 decreased gradually by increasing the amount of 1 × 10–2 M Fe3+ ions in the emulsion, and the emission was quenched more than 60% only at a concentration of 0.2 mM Fe3+ ions, b. Such detection limit is comparable to that of some transition-metal-based PL-CPs. Stern–Volmer equation (SV plot): I 0 /I = 1 + K sv × [M] was applied to judge the quenching effect. As shown in the inset of b, the SV plot shows a good linear behavior, and the K sv value is 0.16 × 105 L·mol–1. The detection limit of 4.7 × 10–4 M for Fe3+ is obtained from the ratio of 3δ/slope, in which δ is the standard deviation of luminescent intensity of blank solution.
elements.clean_text: To investigate if compound 1 can be utilized as a fluorescence probe for sensing metal ions, the fluorescence of 1 dispersed in various 1 × 10-2 M ethanol solutions of metal ions M(NO3) n  (M = Li+, Ca2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Co2+, Mn2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Ag+, Cr3+, Fe3+) were recorded under excitation at 430 nm. As can been seen in  and Figure S7 of Supporting Information, compared with that of the blank sample, the fluorescence intensities of the suspensions were significantly quenched when Fe3+ and Cr3+ ions were added (Figure S8, Supporting Information), while other metal ions only slightly affect the emission intensities. Thus, to explore the sensing sensitivity, we dispersed 2 mg of powder of compound 1 in 2 mL of CH2Cl2 solvent to monitor its emissive response toward the two trivalent metal ions with 1 × 10-2 M concentration. As can be seen in a, the fluorescence intensities of 1 decreased gradually by increasing the amount of 1 × 10-2 M Fe3+ ions in the emulsion, and the emission was quenched more than 60% only at a concentration of 0.2 mM Fe3+ ions, b. Such detection limit is comparable to that of some transition-metal-based PL-CPs. Stern-Volmer equation (SV plot): I 0 /I = 1 + K sv × [M] was applied to judge the quenching effect. As shown in the inset of b, the SV plot shows a good linear behavior, and the K sv value is 0.16 × 105 L⋅mol-1. The detection limit of 4.7 × 10-4 M for Fe3+ is obtained from the ratio of 3δ/slope, in which δ is the standard deviation of luminescent intensity of blank solution.

elements.content: Comparison of the fluorescence intensities of 1 dispersed in various 1 × 10–2 M metal ions.
elements.clean_text: 3  Comparison of the fluorescence intensities of 1 dispersed in various 1 × 10-2 M metal ions.

elements.content: (a) Fluorescence spectra of 1 upon addition of various amounts of 1 × 10–2 M Fe3+ ions. (b) Normalized fluorescence intensities of 1 upon addition of different volumes of 1 × 10–2 M Fe3+ ions. (inset) SV plot responding to Fe3+ ions.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Fluorescence spectra of 1 upon addition of various amounts of 1 × 10-2 M Fe3+ ions. (b) Normalized fluorescence intensities of 1 upon addition of different volumes of 1 × 10-2 M Fe3+ ions. (inset) SV plot responding to Fe3+ ions.

elements.content: On the basis of the same method, the fluorescence intensities of 1 also significantly decreased when Cr3+ ion acted as a quencher, Figure S9 of Supporting Information. As far as we know, the investigation of detection property for Cr3+ via PL-CPs is still rare, exemplified only by NH2–Zn-MOF (MOF = metal–organic framework; dispersed in DMA and DMF, respectively). The fluorescence measurements indicated that the emission intensities of 1 were quenched more than 50% only when 0.6 mM Cr3+ was added. The K sv value for Cr3+ is calculated to be 0.15 × 105 L·mol–1, and the detection limit is 9.6 × 10–4 M. Such detection sensitivity could be comparable to that of NH2–Zn-MOF, whose detection was based on the fluorescence enhancement mechanism. To check the high sensitivity to Fe3+ and Cr3+ over other common interfering metal ions, the competitive experiments were performed at the same fluorescence measurement conditions. It is quite pleasing that the quenching effects by the Fe3+ and Cr3+ ions on the fluorescence of the emulsion of 1 are almost not influenced by the interfering metal ions, Figure S10 of Supporting Information. All the results discussed above indicate that compound 1 should be a good candidate for selective sensing of Fe3+ and Cr3+ ions.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the same method, the fluorescence intensities of 1 also significantly decreased when Cr3+ ion acted as a quencher, Figure S9 of Supporting Information. As far as we know, the investigation of detection property for Cr3+ via PL-CPs is still rare, exemplified only by NH2-Zn-MOF (MOF = metal-organic framework; dispersed in DMA and DMF, respectively). The fluorescence measurements indicated that the emission intensities of 1 were quenched more than 50% only when 0.6 mM Cr3+ was added. The K sv value for Cr3+ is calculated to be 0.15 × 105 L⋅mol-1, and the detection limit is 9.6 × 10-4 M. Such detection sensitivity could be comparable to that of NH2-Zn-MOF, whose detection was based on the fluorescence enhancement mechanism. To check the high sensitivity to Fe3+ and Cr3+ over other common interfering metal ions, the competitive experiments were performed at the same fluorescence measurement conditions. It is quite pleasing that the quenching effects by the Fe3+ and Cr3+ ions on the fluorescence of the emulsion of 1 are almost not influenced by the interfering metal ions, Figure S10 of Supporting Information. All the results discussed above indicate that compound 1 should be a good candidate for selective sensing of Fe3+ and Cr3+ ions.

elements.content: The nitroaromatic compounds of trinitrophenol (TNP), 2,4-dinitraniline, p-nitraniline, and o-nitrophenol as typical unsafe species were further investigated as detection targets to explore the selective sensing property of compound 1. Significantly, the quenched concentrations for nitroaromatics are much lower than those for Fe3+/Cr3+ ions. For instance, the fluorescence was almost completely quenched when only 0.1 mM TNP solution was added (), which is much lower than that of some porous transition-metal (even lanthanide)-based PL-CPs. According to the SV equation, the K sv value is 2.8 × 104 L·mol–1 (inset of b), indicating such detection sensitivity also is better than that of porous PL Mg-CP of Mg5(OH)2(BTEC)2(H2O)4·11H2O, and even comparable to that of some transition-metal-based PL-CPs. On the basis of the quenching mechanism of PL-CPs, the quenched concentrations of TNP for 1 is significantly low suggesting more sensitive detection limits compared to those of other PL-CPs. These results indicate that compound 1 may be applied as a fluorescence sensor for nitroaromatic explosives.
elements.clean_text: The nitroaromatic compounds of trinitrophenol (TNP), 2,4-dinitraniline, p-nitraniline, and o-nitrophenol as typical unsafe species were further investigated as detection targets to explore the selective sensing property of compound 1. Significantly, the quenched concentrations for nitroaromatics are much lower than those for Fe3+/Cr3+ ions. For instance, the fluorescence was almost completely quenched when only 0.1 mM TNP solution was added (), which is much lower than that of some porous transition-metal (even lanthanide)-based PL-CPs. According to the SV equation, the K sv value is 2.8 × 104 L⋅mol-1 (inset of b), indicating such detection sensitivity also is better than that of porous PL Mg-CP of Mg5(OH)2(BTEC)2(H2O)4⋅11H2O, and even comparable to that of some transition-metal-based PL-CPs. On the basis of the quenching mechanism of PL-CPs, the quenched concentrations of TNP for 1 is significantly low suggesting more sensitive detection limits compared to those of other PL-CPs. These results indicate that compound 1 may be applied as a fluorescence sensor for nitroaromatic explosives.

elements.content: (a) Fluorescence spectra of 1 with various contents of TNP. (b) Quenching percentages of fluorescence intensities of 1 by adding different volume of 5 × 10–3 M of TNP. (inset) SV plot responding to TNP.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Fluorescence spectra of 1 with various contents of TNP. (b) Quenching percentages of fluorescence intensities of 1 by adding different volume of 5 × 10-3 M of TNP. (inset) SV plot responding to TNP.

elements.content: The Cr3+ and the paramagnetic high-spin Fe3+ ion with d5 configuration, together with nitroaromatics reported here, have strong electron-withdrawing ability. The electrons of compound 1 excited by photons might be transferred to the quenchers resulting in a decrease of fluorescence intensities of 1. This conclusion could also be identified by further using 2,4-dinitraniline, p-nitraniline, and o-nitrophenol as fluorescence quenchers. The emission of 1 was quenched more than 65% corresponding to the addition of 0.2 mM quencher solution of 2,4-dinitraniline, and the K sv value was calculated to be 0.8 × 104 L·mol–1 (Figure S11, Supporting Information). The emission response to p-nitraniline and o-nitrophenol was also recorded (Figure S12, Supporting Information). However, they showed less sensitive than the polynitro quenchers of TNP. Such results demonstrated that the fluorescence intensities of the title compound sensitively responded to the increasing of the electron-drawing group of −NO3, and the excited electrons of compound 1 were much more easily transferred to polynitro quenchers. Meanwhile, UV–vis absorption spectra of Fe3+ ion and nitro-compounds solution show certain overlap with the excitation spectrum of 1. These results further indicate that the excitation energy absorbed by the organic ligand of 1,4-NDC in 1 could be transferred to the titrants further to quench the fluorescence.
elements.clean_text: The Cr3+ and the paramagnetic high-spin Fe3+ ion with d5 configuration, together with nitroaromatics reported here, have strong electron-withdrawing ability. The electrons of compound 1 excited by photons might be transferred to the quenchers resulting in a decrease of fluorescence intensities of 1. This conclusion could also be identified by further using 2,4-dinitraniline, p-nitraniline, and o-nitrophenol as fluorescence quenchers. The emission of 1 was quenched more than 65% corresponding to the addition of 0.2 mM quencher solution of 2,4-dinitraniline, and the K sv value was calculated to be 0.8 × 104 L⋅mol-1 (Figure S11, Supporting Information). The emission response to p-nitraniline and o-nitrophenol was also recorded (Figure S12, Supporting Information). However, they showed less sensitive than the polynitro quenchers of TNP. Such results demonstrated that the fluorescence intensities of the title compound sensitively responded to the increasing of the electron-drawing group of -NO3, and the excited electrons of compound 1 were much more easily transferred to polynitro quenchers. Meanwhile, UV-vis absorption spectra of Fe3+ ion and nitro-compounds solution show certain overlap with the excitation spectrum of 1. These results further indicate that the excitation energy absorbed by the organic ligand of 1,4-NDC in 1 could be transferred to the titrants further to quench the fluorescence.

elements.content: Photochromic material has recived considerable interest owing to its potential applications in optical switches, decoration, information storage, and so forth. Our group recently reported the first photochromic Mg-CP constructed from non-photoactive ligands. Still, photochromic Mg-CPs have rarely been explored. In this investigation, the dpb was in situ reacted with methanol to form a photochromic cation being incorporated into the host Mg-CP, implying that 1 might own photochromic behavior. Indeed, under the irradiation of Xe lamp for ∼10 min, the light-yellow color of crystals of 1 obviously changed to dark brown, inset of . The ESR spectra of the irradiated sample confirmed such photochromic behavior. The irradiated compound showed a single-peak radical signal (g = 2.004), comparing with a weak ESR signal of 1 before irradiation (). Here [CH3-dpb]+ is a viologen-typed guest that is favorable for the photoinduced reduction, and the g value of the irradiated sample of 2.004 is very close to 2.0023 for typical one free electron. Thus, the paramagnetic center of photochromic 1 should be a radical. UV–vis diffuse reflectance analyses further demonstrated the photochromic property of the title compound clearly. As seen in Figure S13, compared with the original spectrum of 1, a new absorption band around 550 nm appeared, and its intensity enhanced responding to the increase of the irradiation time. As a result, the fluorescence intensity of compound 1 was decreased under different irradiated time (Figure S14, Supporting Information). The dark brown irradiated sample could be returned to its original color after several hours, which indicated a reversible process. The PXRD patterns of the original and coloration samples (Figure S4, Supporting Information) indicated they had the identical crystal structures. All the results mentioned above demonstrate that the photochromic property should be generated from the [CH3-dpb]+ cation within well-defined inner cavities of host Mg-CP.
elements.clean_text:
Photochromic Measurements

Photochromic material has recived considerable interest owing to its potential applications in optical switches, decoration, information storage, and so forth. Our group recently reported the first photochromic Mg-CP constructed from non-photoactive ligands. Still, photochromic Mg-CPs have rarely been explored. In this investigation, the dpb was in situ reacted with methanol to form a photochromic cation being incorporated into the host Mg-CP, implying that 1 might own photochromic behavior. Indeed, under the irradiation of Xe lamp for ~10 min, the light-yellow color of crystals of 1 obviously changed to dark brown, inset of . The ESR spectra of the irradiated sample confirmed such photochromic behavior. The irradiated compound showed a single-peak radical signal (g = 2.004), comparing with a weak ESR signal of 1 before irradiation (). Here [CH3-dpb]+ is a viologen-typed guest that is favorable for the photoinduced reduction, and the g value of the irradiated sample of 2.004 is very close to 2.0023 for typical one free electron. Thus, the paramagnetic center of photochromic 1 should be a radical. UV-vis diffuse reflectance analyses further demonstrated the photochromic property of the title compound clearly. As seen in Figure S13, compared with the original spectrum of 1, a new absorption band around 550 nm appeared, and its intensity enhanced responding to the increase of the irradiation time. As a result, the fluorescence intensity of compound 1 was decreased under different irradiated time (Figure S14, Supporting Information). The dark brown irradiated sample could be returned to its original color after several hours, which indicated a reversible process. The PXRD patterns of the original and coloration samples (Figure S4, Supporting Information) indicated they had the identical crystal structures. All the results mentioned above demonstrate that the photochromic property should be generated from the [CH3-dpb]+ cation within well-defined inner cavities of host Mg-CP.

elements.content: ESR spectra of original (black line) and irradiated sample (red line) of 1. (inset) The photos for corresponding crystals of 1.
elements.clean_text: 6  ESR spectra of original (black line) and irradiated sample (red line) of 1. (inset) The photos for corresponding crystals of 1.

elements.content: In summary, we synthesized and characterized a novel 3D host–guest Mg-CP named as [CH3-dpb]2[Mg3(1,4-NDC)4(μ-H2O)2­(CH3OH)­(H2O)]·1.5H2O (1). Compound 1 demonstrated fluorescence sensing properties for Fe3+/Cr3+ metal ions and nitro-explosive compounds. It is noticed that 1 presents the first fluorescent Mg-CP exhibiting fluorescence sensing behavior for metal ions. Additionally, as in situ encapsulation of photochromic [CH3-dpb] guest, compound 1 exhibited unusual photochromic behavior with reversible color changes. Future study will be focused on the exploration of new fluorescent Mg-CP sensors and deep understanding of relationship of structure and property.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we synthesized and characterized a novel 3D host-guest Mg-CP named as [CH3-dpb]2[Mg3(1,4-NDC)4(μ-H2O)2(CH3OH)(H2O)]⋅1.5H2O (1). Compound 1 demonstrated fluorescence sensing properties for Fe3+/Cr3+ metal ions and nitro-explosive compounds. It is noticed that 1 presents the first fluorescent Mg-CP exhibiting fluorescence sensing behavior for metal ions. Additionally, as in situ encapsulation of photochromic [CH3-dpb] guest, compound 1 exhibited unusual photochromic behavior with reversible color changes. Future study will be focused on the exploration of new fluorescent Mg-CP sensors and deep understanding of relationship of structure and property.

cln_elements.content: The reactants of Mg­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.256 g, 1 mmol), 1,4-H2NDC (0.216 g, 1 mmol), dpb (0.232 g, 1 mmol), and NaOH (0.080 g, 2 mmol) were mixed with 2 mL of CH3OH and 2 mL of H2O, and then the mixture was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and kept at 160 °C for 6 d. After the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, the blocklike yellow crystals were obtained after filtered, washed with ethanol several times, dried naturally, and selected manually under an optical microscope (0.120 g, yield: 23% based on magnesium). Anal. Calcd for 1: C, 64.84%; H, 4.39%; N, 3.64%. Found: C, 63.46%; H, 4.35%; N, 3.59%.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compound 1 

The reactants of Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.256 g, 1 mmol), 1,4-H2NDC (0.216 g, 1 mmol), dpb (0.232 g, 1 mmol), and NaOH (0.080 g, 2 mmol) were mixed with 2 mL of CH3OH and 2 mL of H2O, and then the mixture was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and kept at 160 °C for 6 d. After the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, the blocklike yellow crystals were obtained after filtered, washed with ethanol several times, dried naturally, and selected manually under an optical microscope (0.120 g, yield: 23% based on magnesium). Anal. Calcd for 1: C, 64.84%; H, 4.39%; N, 3.64%. Found: C, 63.46%; H, 4.35%; N, 3.59%.

metadata.title:
A Mg-CP with in Situ Encapsulated
Photochromic Guest as Sensitive Fluorescence Sensor for Fe3+/Cr3+ Ions and Nitro-Explosives
